canonical_explanation.text: The nucleus of an atom contains protons and neutrons (collectively called nucleons). The atomic number Z gives the number of protons, the mass number A gives the total number of nucleons, and N = A - Z is the number of neutrons. Isotopes have the same Z but different A; isobars have the same A but different Z; isotones have the same N. The nuclear radius follows R = R_0 A^(1/3), where R_0 = 1.2 fm. Since volume is proportional to A and mass is approximately A u, the nuclear density is nearly constant (about 2.3 x 10^17 kg/m^3) for all nuclei. The mass of a nucleus is less than the sum of the masses of its constituent nucleons; this difference is the mass defect: Delta_m = [Z m_p + (A-Z) m_n] - M_nucleus. By Einstein's mass-energy relation E = mc^2, this mass defect corresponds to the binding energy: B.E. = Delta_m x c^2 = Delta_m x 931.5 MeV. The binding energy per nucleon (B.E./A) peaks around A = 56 (iron), indicating maximum stability. Nuclei with very high or very low A have lower B.E./A and can release energy via fission or fusion respectively. Radioactivity is the spontaneous emission of alpha, beta, or gamma radiation. The decay law is N = N_0 e^(-lambda t), where lambda is the decay constant. Half-life T_(1/2) = 0.693/lambda. Mean life tau = 1/lambda = T_(1/2)/0.693. In alpha decay, the mass number decreases by 4 and atomic number by 2. In beta-minus decay, a neutron converts to a proton (Z increases by 1, A unchanged). Nuclear fission is the splitting of a heavy nucleus (e.g., U-235) into two lighter fragments with release of energy. Nuclear fusion is the combining of light nuclei (e.g., hydrogen isotopes) to form a heavier nucleus with release of energy, as in stars.
rules: Nuclear radius: R = R_0 A^(1/3), where R_0 = 1.2 fm; nuclear density is approximately constant for all nuclei
Mass defect: Delta_m = [Z m_p + (A-Z) m_n] - M_nucleus
Binding energy: B.E. = Delta_m x 931.5 MeV (using 1 u = 931.5 MeV/c^2)
B.E. per nucleon peaks near A = 56 (iron); nuclei with A near 56 are most stable
Radioactive decay law: N = N_0 e^(-lambda t); Activity A = lambda N = A_0 e^(-lambda t)
Half-life: T_(1/2) = 0.693/lambda; after n half-lives, N = N_0/2^n
Alpha decay: A decreases by 4, Z decreases by 2; Beta-minus decay: Z increases by 1, A unchanged
Fission: heavy nucleus splits into lighter fragments; Fusion: light nuclei combine; both release energy

questions.question_text: The nucleus of an atom contains:
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus contains protons (positively charged) and neutrons (electrically neutral), collectively called nucleons. Electrons orbit the nucleus outside it and are not part of the nuclear composition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons are not inside the nucleus; they orbit around it. The nucleus is made up of protons and neutrons only. The discovery of the neutron by Chadwick (1932) completed the nuclear composition picture.

questions.question_text: The nuclear radius is proportional to:
questions.explanation_correct: The nuclear radius follows R = R_0 A^(1/3), where R_0 is approximately 1.2 fm and A is the mass number. This implies the nuclear volume V = (4/3)pi R^3 is proportional to A, meaning each nucleon occupies roughly the same volume.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The radius follows R = R_0 A^(1/3), not A, A^(1/2), or A^2. The 1/3 power arises because nuclear volume is proportional to A (constant density), and V = (4/3)pi R^3, so R is proportional to A^(1/3).

questions.question_text: Isotopes of an element have:

options.text: Same mass number but different atomic number
Same atomic number but different mass number
Same number of neutrons but different number of protons
Same atomic number and same mass number

questions.explanation_correct: Isotopes are atoms of the same element with the same atomic number Z (same number of protons) but different mass numbers A (different number of neutrons). For example, hydrogen (H-1), deuterium (H-2), and tritium (H-3) are isotopes of hydrogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isotopes have the same Z (atomic number) but different A (mass number). Atoms with same A but different Z are called isobars, not isotopes. Atoms with the same number of neutrons are called isotones.

questions.question_text: The density of nuclear matter is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The nuclear density is approximately 2.3 x 10^17 kg/m^3, which is nearly constant for all nuclei regardless of their mass number. This is because both the mass and volume of the nucleus are proportional to A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 10^3 kg/m^3 is the density of water. Nuclear matter is extraordinarily dense because a huge mass is packed into a tiny volume. The nuclear density of about 2.3 x 10^17 kg/m^3 is the same for all nuclei, reflecting the constant nucleon packing density.

questions.question_text: The ratio of nuclear radii of two nuclei with mass numbers 27 and 64 is:
questions.explanation_correct: R = R_0 A^(1/3). R_1/R_2 = (A_1/A_2)^(1/3) = (27/64)^(1/3) = 3/4. The cube root of 27 is 3 and the cube root of 64 is 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nuclear radius is proportional to A^(1/3), not A. So the ratio of radii is (27/64)^(1/3) = 3/4, not 27/64. Taking cube roots: 27^(1/3) = 3 and 64^(1/3) = 4.

questions.question_text: Two nuclei have mass numbers in the ratio 1:8. The ratio of their nuclear radii is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nuclear radius is proportional to A^(1/3). So if A_1:A_2 = 1:8, then R_1:R_2 = 1^(1/3):8^(1/3) = 1:2. The volume ratio would be 1:8 (proportional to A), but the radius ratio is 1:2.

questions.question_text: The nuclear density does not depend on mass number A because:

options.text: Both nuclear mass and volume are proportional to A
Protons and neutrons have different masses

questions.explanation_correct: Nuclear density = mass/volume. Mass is approximately A u (proportional to A). Volume = (4/3)pi R^3 = (4/3)pi R_0^3 A (proportional to A). So density = A u / [(4/3)pi R_0^3 A] = u / [(4/3)pi R_0^3], which is independent of A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The constancy of nuclear density is a mathematical consequence of both mass and volume being proportional to A. When you divide mass (proportional to A) by volume (proportional to A), the A cancels out, making density independent of A.

questions.question_text: If the radius of a nucleus with mass number A = 125 is R, then the radius of a nucleus with A = 64 is:
The number of nucleons in a nucleus of radius 3.6 fm is approximately: (R_0 = 1.2 fm)
questions.explanation_correct: R = R_0 A^(1/3), so A = (R/R_0)^3 = (3.6/1.2)^3 = 3^3 = 27. The nucleus has approximately 27 nucleons. This corresponds to aluminium-27 (Al-27).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using R = R_0 A^(1/3): A = (R/R_0)^3 = (3.6/1.2)^3 = 3^3 = 27. The mass number is 27, not 9 or 64. Always cube the ratio R/R_0 to find A.

questions.question_text: The mass defect of a nucleus is defined as:

options.text: The difference between the mass of the nucleus and the mass of a single nucleon
The difference between the sum of masses of constituent nucleons and the actual mass of the nucleus
The mass of the nucleus divided by the mass number
The mass of the nucleus minus the mass of the electrons

questions.explanation_correct: The mass defect is Delta_m = [Z m_p + (A-Z) m_n] - M_nucleus. It is the difference between the total mass of the individual nucleons (if they were free) and the actual mass of the nucleus. This mass has been converted to binding energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mass defect is not about a single nucleon or about electrons. It is the difference between the sum of the masses of all constituent protons and neutrons (if free) and the actual nuclear mass. This 'missing mass' is converted into binding energy via E = mc^2.

questions.question_text: The energy equivalent of 1 atomic mass unit (1 u) is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Using E = mc^2: 1 u = 1.66054 x 10^-27 kg. E = 1.66054 x 10^-27 x (3 x 10^8)^2 = 1.4924 x 10^-10 J = 931.5 MeV. This is a fundamental conversion factor used in nuclear physics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 13.6 eV is the ionisation energy of hydrogen. 1.6 x 10^-19 J = 1 eV. 511 keV is the rest energy of an electron. The energy equivalent of 1 u is 931.5 MeV, used extensively in nuclear mass-energy calculations.

questions.question_text: The binding energy of a nucleus represents:

options.text: The energy needed to remove one nucleon from the nucleus
The energy released when nucleons come together to form the nucleus
The kinetic energy of nucleons inside the nucleus

questions.explanation_correct: The binding energy is the energy released when individual nucleons combine to form a nucleus, or equivalently, the energy required to completely separate all nucleons of a nucleus. It equals Delta_m x c^2, where Delta_m is the mass defect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The energy to remove one nucleon is the separation energy, not the total binding energy. The binding energy is the total energy that holds all nucleons together, equal to the energy released during formation or needed for complete disassembly of the nucleus.

questions.question_text: The binding energy per nucleon is maximum for nuclei with mass number near:
questions.explanation_correct: The binding energy per nucleon (B.E./A) curve peaks around A = 56 (iron-56), where B.E./A is about 8.75 MeV per nucleon. This makes iron and nearby nuclei the most stable. Both lighter and heavier nuclei have lower B.E./A values.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A = 4 (helium) has an unusually high B.E./A for light nuclei but is not the overall maximum. A = 238 (uranium) has a lower B.E./A (about 7.6 MeV). The peak is at A = 56 (iron), which is why iron is the end product of stellar nucleosynthesis.

questions.question_text: A nucleus has mass defect of 0.05 u. Its binding energy is approximately:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The binding energy equals the mass defect times 931.5 MeV/u. B.E. = 0.05 u x 931.5 MeV/u = 46.575 MeV. Make sure to multiply (not divide) the mass defect by 931.5.

questions.question_text: The mass of a He-4 nucleus is 4.0015 u. Given m_p = 1.0073 u and m_n = 1.0087 u, the mass defect is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Delta_m = [Z m_p + N m_n] - M = [2(1.0073) + 2(1.0087)] - 4.0015 = 4.0320 - 4.0015 = 0.0305 u. Both proton and neutron masses must be used with their correct multiplicities.

questions.question_text: For a nucleus with binding energy per nucleon of 8.5 MeV and mass number 56, the total binding energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total binding energy = (B.E./A) x A = 8.5 x 56 = 476 MeV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The total binding energy is simply the binding energy per nucleon multiplied by the number of nucleons: 8.5 MeV x 56 = 476 MeV.

questions.question_text: The binding energy per nucleon for deuterium (H-2) is 1.1 MeV and for He-4 it is 7.0 MeV. The energy released when two deuterium nuclei fuse to form one He-4 nucleus is:
questions.explanation_correct: B.E. of two deuterium nuclei = 2 x (2 x 1.1) = 4.4 MeV. B.E. of He-4 = 4 x 7.0 = 28.0 MeV. Energy released = 28.0 - 4.4 = 23.6 MeV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy released = B.E.(products) - B.E.(reactants) = (4 x 7.0) - (2 x 2 x 1.1) = 28.0 - 4.4 = 23.6 MeV. The higher binding energy of the product means energy is released in the process.

questions.question_text: In the binding energy per nucleon curve, energy can be released by:

options.text: Both fission of heavy nuclei and fusion of light nuclei

questions.explanation_correct: The B.E./A curve peaks around A = 56. Energy is released when nuclei move towards higher B.E./A: heavy nuclei (low B.E./A) can split (fission) and light nuclei (low B.E./A) can combine (fusion), both moving towards the peak.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both fission of heavy nuclei and fusion of light nuclei release energy because both processes result in products with higher binding energy per nucleon. In both cases, the products are closer to the peak of the B.E./A curve near A = 56.

questions.question_text: The mass of a C-12 atom is defined as exactly 12 u. The mass of its nucleus is:
questions.explanation_correct: The atom includes 6 electrons. The nuclear mass = atomic mass - mass of 6 electrons + binding energy of electrons (negligible). So the nuclear mass is approximately 12 - 6 x 0.00055 u = 11.9967 u, which is less than 12 u. Also, 6m_p + 6m_n > nuclear mass due to mass defect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 12 u is the atomic mass (including 6 electrons). The nuclear mass is less than the atomic mass because the 6 electrons have mass. Also, the nuclear mass is less than 6m_p + 6m_n due to the mass defect (binding energy).

questions.question_text: Radioactivity is:

options.text: The spontaneous disintegration of unstable nuclei with emission of radiation
Emission of light from excited atoms

questions.explanation_correct: Radioactivity is the spontaneous and random process by which unstable nuclei disintegrate, emitting alpha particles, beta particles, or gamma rays. It is a nuclear phenomenon, not a chemical or atomic one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Radioactivity is a nuclear phenomenon, not chemical. It involves the spontaneous emission of radiation from unstable nuclei. Light emission from excited atoms is a different process (atomic spectra). Radioactivity involves emission, not absorption.

questions.question_text: The radioactive decay law states that the number of undecayed nuclei at time t is:
questions.explanation_correct: The radioactive decay law is N = N_0 e^(-lambda t), where N_0 is the initial number of nuclei, lambda is the decay constant, and t is the time elapsed. This exponential decay arises from the fact that the rate of decay is proportional to the number of undecayed nuclei: dN/dt = -lambda N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The decay is exponential, not linear. N = N_0 e^(-lambda t) shows the number decreases exponentially with time. N = N_0 e^(lambda t) would represent exponential growth, which is incorrect for radioactive decay.

questions.question_text: The half-life of a radioactive substance is related to the decay constant lambda by:
questions.explanation_correct: At t = T_(1/2), N = N_0/2. So N_0/2 = N_0 e^(-lambda T_(1/2)), giving e^(-lambda T_(1/2)) = 1/2, hence lambda T_(1/2) = ln 2 = 0.693. Therefore T_(1/2) = 0.693/lambda.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T_(1/2) = 0.693/lambda, not lambda/0.693 or 1/lambda. The factor 0.693 = ln 2 appears because the half-life is defined as the time for half the nuclei to decay. The mean life tau = 1/lambda is different from the half-life.

questions.question_text: After 3 half-lives, the fraction of the original radioactive sample remaining is:
questions.explanation_correct: After n half-lives, the fraction remaining is (1/2)^n. After 3 half-lives: (1/2)^3 = 1/8. So only 1/8 of the original sample remains undecayed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fraction remaining after n half-lives is (1/2)^n, not 1/(2n) or 1/(n+1). After 3 half-lives: (1/2)^3 = 1/8. Each half-life reduces the remaining amount by half: 1/2, 1/4, 1/8.

questions.question_text: A radioactive element has a half-life of 10 days. After 40 days, what fraction of the original sample will have decayed?
questions.explanation_correct: Number of half-lives = 40/10 = 4. Fraction remaining = (1/2)^4 = 1/16. Fraction decayed = 1 - 1/16 = 15/16.
questions.explanation_incorrect: After 4 half-lives, 1/16 of the sample remains. The fraction that has decayed is 1 - 1/16 = 15/16. Note the question asks for the fraction decayed, not the fraction remaining.

questions.question_text: The activity of a radioactive sample is 800 disintegrations per second. After 3 half-lives, the activity will be:
questions.explanation_correct: Activity also follows the exponential decay law: A = A_0 (1/2)^n, where n is the number of half-lives. A = 800 x (1/2)^3 = 800/8 = 100 dps.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Activity decays in the same way as the number of nuclei. After 3 half-lives: A = 800/(2^3) = 800/8 = 100 dps. Activity halves with each half-life: 800 -> 400 -> 200 -> 100.

questions.question_text: The mean life of a radioactive sample is 100 s. Its half-life is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Mean life tau = 1/lambda = 100 s. Half-life T_(1/2) = 0.693/lambda = 0.693 x tau = 0.693 x 100 = 69.3 s. The half-life is always shorter than the mean life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T_(1/2) = 0.693 x tau = 0.693 x 100 = 69.3 s. The half-life and mean life are related by the factor 0.693 (= ln 2). The half-life is about 69.3% of the mean life.

questions.question_text: In alpha decay, the mass number and atomic number of the daughter nucleus change by:

options.text: A decreases by 2, Z decreases by 1
A decreases by 4, Z decreases by 2
A remains same, Z increases by 1
A decreases by 4, Z decreases by 4

questions.explanation_correct: An alpha particle is a helium-4 nucleus (2 protons + 2 neutrons). In alpha decay: X(A,Z) -> Y(A-4, Z-2) + He-4(4,2). The mass number decreases by 4 and atomic number decreases by 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An alpha particle has A = 4, Z = 2. So in alpha decay, the parent loses 4 nucleons (A decreases by 4) and 2 protons (Z decreases by 2). Option C describes beta-minus decay, not alpha decay.

questions.question_text: A radioactive sample has N_0 active nuclei at t = 0. At t = 2T_(1/2), the number of decayed nuclei is:
questions.explanation_correct: After 2 half-lives, remaining nuclei = N_0/4. Decayed nuclei = N_0 - N_0/4 = 3N_0/4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: After 2 half-lives, the fraction remaining is (1/2)^2 = 1/4. So N_remaining = N_0/4 and N_decayed = N_0 - N_0/4 = 3N_0/4. Don't confuse the remaining fraction with the decayed fraction.

questions.question_text: The half-life of a radioactive substance is 30 minutes. The time taken for 75% of the substance to decay is:
questions.explanation_correct: If 75% has decayed, 25% remains: N/N_0 = 1/4 = (1/2)^2. So n = 2 half-lives. Time = 2 x 30 = 60 minutes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 75% decayed means 25% = 1/4 remains. (1/2)^n = 1/4 gives n = 2. Time = 2 x 30 = 60 minutes. Don't confuse: 75% decay requires 2 half-lives (not 1.5).

questions.question_text: In beta-minus decay, the particle emitted along with the electron is:
questions.explanation_correct: In beta-minus decay, a neutron converts to a proton, an electron, and an antineutrino: n -> p + e^- + antineutrino. The antineutrino was postulated by Pauli to explain the continuous energy spectrum of beta particles and to conserve energy, momentum, and lepton number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The beta-minus decay process is n -> p + e^- + antineutrino. The antineutrino carries away part of the energy, which explains why beta particles have a continuous energy spectrum rather than a discrete one. A positron is emitted in beta-plus decay, not beta-minus.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of radioactive activity is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of radioactive activity is the Becquerel (Bq), defined as 1 disintegration per second. The Curie (Ci) is an older non-SI unit equal to 3.7 x 10^10 disintegrations per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Curie is a traditional unit (not SI). The Rutherford is another non-SI unit. The Roentgen is a unit of radiation exposure. The SI unit of activity is the Becquerel (Bq) = 1 disintegration per second.

questions.question_text: Nuclear fission is the process in which:

options.text: Two light nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus
A heavy nucleus splits into two or more lighter nuclei
A nucleus emits an alpha particle

questions.explanation_correct: Nuclear fission is the splitting of a heavy nucleus (like U-235) into two or more lighter nuclei (fission fragments) along with the release of neutrons and a large amount of energy. It was discovered by Hahn and Strassmann in 1938.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Combining light nuclei is fusion, not fission. Emitting an alpha particle is alpha decay. Fission specifically refers to the splitting of a heavy nucleus into lighter fragments, typically induced by neutron bombardment.

questions.question_text: Nuclear fusion requires very high temperatures because:

options.text: Light nuclei have low binding energy
The nuclei need to overcome the strong Coulomb repulsion between them

questions.explanation_correct: For fusion to occur, the positively charged nuclei must come close enough for the short-range nuclear force to act. This requires overcoming the electrostatic Coulomb repulsion between the protons, which needs extremely high kinetic energies (temperatures of millions of kelvin).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fusion is exothermic (releases energy), not endothermic. The high temperature is needed to give the nuclei enough kinetic energy to overcome the Coulomb barrier. At millions of kelvin, matter exists as plasma and nuclei can approach close enough for the nuclear force to bind them.

questions.question_text: The source of energy in the Sun is:
questions.explanation_correct: The Sun derives its energy from nuclear fusion reactions in its core, primarily the proton-proton chain where hydrogen nuclei fuse to form helium. The temperature at the core is about 15 million K, sufficient to overcome the Coulomb barrier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chemical combustion would be far too weak to sustain the Sun's energy output. Nuclear fission is used in nuclear reactors but is not the Sun's energy source. The Sun's energy comes from fusion of hydrogen into helium, releasing about 26.7 MeV per reaction cycle.

questions.question_text: In the fission of U-235, about 200 MeV of energy is released per fission. The energy released per nucleon is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Energy per nucleon = 200 MeV / 235 = 0.851 MeV per nucleon, approximately 0.85 MeV. This represents the difference in binding energy per nucleon between the parent (U-235) and the fission products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Total energy per fission is about 200 MeV. Dividing by the 235 nucleons: 200/235 = 0.85 MeV per nucleon. This is much less than the total B.E./A but represents the energy released per nucleon during fission.

questions.question_text: The chain reaction in nuclear fission is sustained because:

options.text: Neutrons produced in fission cause further fissions

questions.explanation_correct: In nuclear fission, typically 2-3 neutrons are released per fission event. These neutrons can go on to cause further fissions in nearby fissile nuclei, creating a chain reaction. For a sustained chain reaction, the neutron multiplication factor k must be at least 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The chain reaction is sustained by neutrons, not gamma rays, alpha particles, or temperature alone. Each fission of U-235 releases 2-3 neutrons, and if at least one of these causes another fission, the chain reaction continues.

questions.question_text: The material used as a moderator in a nuclear reactor to slow down neutrons is:
questions.explanation_correct: Moderators like heavy water (D2O) and graphite are used to slow down fast neutrons to thermal energies. Slow (thermal) neutrons have a much higher probability of causing fission in U-235. The moderator material should have low mass number for efficient energy transfer and low neutron absorption.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cadmium rods are control rods (they absorb neutrons to control the chain reaction), not moderators. U-235 and Pu-239 are fissile fuels. Moderators (heavy water, graphite) slow down neutrons through elastic collisions.

questions.question_text: In a nuclear reactor, the purpose of the control rods (usually cadmium or boron) is to:

options.text: Absorb excess neutrons to control the chain reaction

questions.explanation_correct: Control rods made of cadmium or boron are strong neutron absorbers. By inserting or withdrawing them from the reactor core, the rate of the chain reaction can be controlled, keeping the multiplication factor k = 1 for steady power output.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Slowing down neutrons is the job of the moderator. Shielding and cooling are done by other components. Control rods specifically absorb neutrons to regulate the chain reaction. When fully inserted, they can shut down the reactor by absorbing too many neutrons for the chain reaction to sustain.

questions.question_text: A nucleus undergoes two alpha decays and one beta-minus decay. The resulting changes in mass number and atomic number are:

options.text: A decreases by 8, Z decreases by 4
A decreases by 8, Z decreases by 3
A decreases by 4, Z decreases by 1
A decreases by 8, Z decreases by 5

questions.explanation_correct: Two alpha decays: A decreases by 2 x 4 = 8, Z decreases by 2 x 2 = 4. One beta-minus decay: A unchanged, Z increases by 1. Net: A decreases by 8, Z decreases by 4 - 1 = 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each alpha decay: Delta_A = -4, Delta_Z = -2. Each beta-minus: Delta_A = 0, Delta_Z = +1. Two alphas + one beta: Delta_A = -8, Delta_Z = -4 + 1 = -3. So A decreases by 8 and Z decreases by 3.

questions.question_text: Which of the following nuclei has the highest binding energy per nucleon?
questions.explanation_correct: Fe-56 has the highest binding energy per nucleon (about 8.75 MeV), making it the most stable nucleus. This is the peak of the B.E./A curve. He-4 has about 7.07 MeV/nucleon, H-2 about 1.1 MeV/nucleon, and U-238 about 7.6 MeV/nucleon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although He-4 has an unusually high B.E./A for light nuclei, Fe-56 has the highest overall. U-238, being very heavy, has a lower B.E./A than Fe-56. The peak of the B.E./A curve is at Fe-56.

questions.question_text: Isobars are atoms that have:

options.text: Same atomic number but different mass numbers
Same mass number but different atomic numbers
Same atomic number and mass number

questions.explanation_correct: Isobars are atoms of different elements that have the same mass number A but different atomic numbers Z. For example, C-14 (Z=6) and N-14 (Z=7) are isobars with A = 14.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same Z, different A defines isotopes (not isobars). Same N defines isotones. Isobars have the same mass number A but different atomic numbers Z, meaning they are different elements with the same total number of nucleons.

questions.question_text: The half-life of a radioactive element is 8 hours. Its mean life is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Mean life tau = T_(1/2) / 0.693 = 8 / 0.693 = 11.54 hours. The mean life is always longer than the half-life by a factor of 1/0.693 = 1.443.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mean life is not equal to the half-life. tau = T_(1/2)/ln 2 = T_(1/2)/0.693 = 8/0.693 = 11.54 hours. The mean life is about 44% longer than the half-life.

questions.question_text: The nuclear force between two nucleons is:
questions.explanation_correct: The nuclear force is short-range (effective up to about 2-3 fm), charge-independent (same between p-p, n-n, p-n pairs), and shows saturation (each nucleon interacts only with its nearest neighbours). It is strongly attractive at distances of 1-2 fm but becomes repulsive at very short distances (< 0.7 fm).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nuclear force is not long-range like gravity or electrostatics. It is a short-range force that acts only between neighbouring nucleons. It is charge-independent (does not depend on whether the nucleons are protons or neutrons) and exhibits the property of saturation.

questions.question_text: In a nuclear fission reaction: U-235 + n -> Ba-141 + Kr-92 + x n, the value of x is:
questions.explanation_correct: Conserving mass number: 235 + 1 = 141 + 92 + x(1), so 236 = 233 + x, giving x = 3. Three neutrons are produced in this particular fission reaction. These neutrons can cause further fissions, sustaining the chain reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By conservation of mass number: 235 + 1 = 141 + 92 + x. So 236 = 233 + x, x = 3. We can verify with atomic number: 92 + 0 = 56 + 36 + 0, which gives 92 = 92 (consistent). Three neutrons are released.

questions.question_text: The binding energy per nucleon of O-16 is 7.97 MeV and that of O-17 is 7.75 MeV. The energy needed to remove one neutron from O-17 is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: B.E. of O-17 = 17 x 7.75 = 131.75 MeV. B.E. of O-16 = 16 x 7.97 = 127.52 MeV. Energy to remove one neutron = B.E.(O-17) - B.E.(O-16) = 131.75 - 127.52 = 4.23 MeV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When a neutron is removed from O-17, the remaining nucleus is O-16. The neutron separation energy is the difference in total binding energies: 17(7.75) - 16(7.97) = 131.75 - 127.52 = 4.23 MeV.

questions.question_text: Gamma rays emitted during radioactive decay are:
questions.explanation_correct: Gamma rays are high-energy electromagnetic radiation (photons) emitted by a nucleus in an excited state transitioning to a lower energy state. They have no mass or charge, travel at the speed of light, and are the most penetrating form of nuclear radiation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons (beta-minus particles) and helium nuclei (alpha particles) are different types of nuclear radiation. Gamma rays are not particles but electromagnetic radiation with very short wavelengths and high energy.

questions.question_text: Energy released per fusion reaction (4 protons forming He-4) in the Sun is approximately 26 MeV. The energy released per nucleon is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Energy per nucleon = 26 MeV / 4 nucleons = 6.5 MeV per nucleon. This is much higher than the energy per nucleon from fission (about 0.85 MeV), which is why fusion produces much more energy per unit mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Four protons are involved in the fusion reaction, so energy per nucleon = 26/4 = 6.5 MeV. This is significantly higher than the 0.85 MeV per nucleon for fission, explaining why fusion is a more efficient energy source.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is used as nuclear fuel in a reactor?
questions.explanation_correct: U-235 is a fissile material used as nuclear fuel. It undergoes fission when struck by slow (thermal) neutrons. U-238, though more abundant, is not fissile (it is fertile and can be converted to Pu-239). Pb-206 is the stable end product of radioactive decay chains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: U-238 is fertile but not fissile; it does not undergo fission with slow neutrons. Pb-206 is a stable isotope. C-12 is used as a moderator (graphite), not as fuel. U-235 is the only naturally occurring fissile isotope used as nuclear fuel.

questions.question_text: A radioactive nucleus emits one alpha particle and two beta-minus particles sequentially. The resulting daughter nucleus has:

options.text: A decreased by 4, Z decreased by 4
A decreased by 4, Z decreased by 2

questions.explanation_correct: Alpha decay: A -> A-4, Z -> Z-2. Two beta-minus decays: A unchanged, Z -> Z-2+2 = Z. Net result: A decreases by 4, Z returns to the original value (Z unchanged). The daughter is an isotope of the parent with mass number reduced by 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One alpha decay gives Delta_A = -4, Delta_Z = -2. Two beta-minus decays give Delta_A = 0, Delta_Z = +2. Net: Delta_A = -4, Delta_Z = -2+2 = 0. The mass number decreases by 4 but the atomic number is unchanged.

questions.question_text: If the nuclear radius of Al-27 is 3.6 fm, the nuclear radius of Te-125 is approximately:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the ratio: R_Te/R_Al = (A_Te/A_Al)^(1/3) = (125/27)^(1/3) = 5/3. So R_Te = 3.6 x 5/3 = 6.0 fm. The cube roots of 125 and 27 are 5 and 3 respectively.
